text:
Hello :wave::skin-tone-3:

I have a bit silly question, but I wonder -- what kind of email pitches (or other kind of messages) convince you to add someone's link when they point a broken link on your website?

From time to time, I receive emails with people pointing out broken links at Tidio's blog, and even though it's cool they do this outreach (instead of: give me a link), I *never ever added or replaced* the broken link with the resource they suggested. Mainly because *the emails sucked* and they were so self-promotional.

How about you? Have you ever replaced your broken link with the resource someone sent you? What made you do it? What are the best pitches you received?

How about you? Have you ever replaced your broken link with the resource someone sent you? What made you do it? What are the best pitches you received?

text: Hello, all! Are there any Canadians in here who specialize in eCommerce content (think house furnishings)? Or, are there any folks who know of or have worked with Canadian content agencies that are in this market? A woman I know is interested in hiring a content agency that works in producing content in this niche and she only wants a Canadian agency. All of my eCommerce contacts in this area are in the US, so I'm of no help. She's looking for a personal connection, so ye ol' Google is out. Thank you!!

text:
I run a service that does exactly this. We convert your podcasts, webinars, conference talks, etc. into blog posts and promotional assets like social media posts, graphics, audiograms, video snippets, and so on.

Some of my clients use them to produce case studies for their service business. Most of them use the podcast episode as source material for a new piece of content that establishes their expertise or authority. In the case of a guest with a big profile/audience, they’ll take the approach of “5 Things We Learned About (Topic) from (Expert).”

Lots of ways to get creative with it. Happy to talk podcast promotion and repurposing strategy anytime!

text:
A bit of a selfish, targeted question here…

Is anyone in the B2B services space (think creative agencies) and testing high volume, low commercial intent keywords versus low volume, high commercial intent keywords? Curious how you’ve set up your test and if you’ve seen better results in one area or another.

As a hypothetical example, if I’m looking at a spreadsheet with “ecommerce conversion rate” (5,000 monthly searches, KD 24) and “best CRO agency” (100 monthly searches, KD 24) and I only have the time/budget to go after one, which one should I prioritize?

Seems like I have a better chance of finding one client from 5,000 searches per month than 100 per month, even though the latter group is further along in the funnel. But I know a lot of folks might argue otherwise.

elements.text:

As a hypothetical example, if I’m looking at a spreadsheet with “ecommerce conversion rate” (5,000 monthly searches, KD 24) and “best CRO agency” (100 monthly searches, KD 24) and I only have the time/budget to go after one, which one should I prioritize?

Seems like I have a better chance of finding one client from 5,000 searches per month than 100 per month, even though the latter group is further along in the funnel. But I know a lot of folks might argue otherwise.

text:
i've seen way better results from targeting low-volume, high-intent KWs than the other way around. like, consistent direct conversions from a KW that ahrefs gives 0-10 volume for.

in your example i would not target "ecommerce conversion rate" because that's such an informational KW you're not likely to get any conversions from it

elements.text:
i've seen way better results from targeting low-volume, high-intent KWs than the other way around. like, consistent direct conversions from a KW that ahrefs gives 0-10 volume for.

in your example i would not target "ecommerce conversion rate" because that's such an informational KW you're not likely to get any conversions from it

text: how i think of it is that it's always better to start lower down in the funnel since those people are more likely to be "hot" leads. providing info on a topic that's more closely related to your business is the better way to go if you don't have any content to start with — then once you've covered all of the late funnel stuff you can move on to building out the rest of your funnel and attracting less qualified leads

text: go for higher intent & eventually work your way up to "ecommerce conversion rate" You'll build credibility w/ google if you start lower in the funnel with lower volume keywords

text:
<@UL2E0QVB3>, I think my top tip would be making a sticky CTA for the sidebar.

For example, if I go to <https://learn.genbook.com/small-business-marketing-budget-planner/>, there are “Quick Links” there, but what would probably work better is a box with an email capture field that links to a specific asset, or, maybe better, links to a signup for a newsletter or some other community-oriented thing that lets you keep in touch with these prospects.

Other than that I didn’t see anything super obvious, but talking with some of your customers would probably help – see what it’s like for them to be on the blog and what they think your company is about.

attachments.service_name: [Genbook Learning Center] ?Lessons to build better business experience
attachments.title: How to Create a Marketing Budget? A Refresher For Your Spa, Salon or Barbershop
attachments.text: Marketing budget: how to build one for your spa, salon, or barbershop. Read along to find tips, sample budget, and free planning template.
attachments.fallback: [Genbook Learning Center] ?Lessons to build better business experience: How to Create a Marketing Budget? A Refresher For Your Spa, Salon or Barbershop

text: I don’t do it. I think it creates a deeper relationship between you and the client/you and the freelancer and that’s usually enough for me. I am just about trying to help others when I can. I think people are naturally appreciative and will likely refer you for opportunities on the client and freelancer side if you just try your best to be helpful and make connections.

text: Hi, everyone! I’m working to set up a GA dashboard for a client that wants to track blog traffic. The problem: they don’t post their blogs in a dedicated folder, just off the root domain. We’ve pushed them to change that, but it’s a big lift and I’m not optimistic that they’ll do it. So I’m wondering: is there a workaround that will let me track blog-only traffic in GA? (Note: I am pretty inexperienced in GA, so apologies if there is a really obvious answer.)

elements.text: Hi, everyone! I’m working to set up a GA dashboard for a client that wants to track blog traffic. The problem: they don’t post their blogs in a dedicated folder, just off the root domain. We’ve pushed them to change that, but it’s a big lift and I’m not optimistic that they’ll do it. So I’m wondering: is there a workaround that will let me track blog-only traffic in GA? (Note: I am pretty inexperienced in GA, so apologies if there is a really obvious answer.)

text: Appreciate the input!

elements.text: Appreciate the input!

text: somebody more experienced than me might help, but my first thought is—could you create a segment that includes those URLs only?

elements.text: somebody more experienced than me might help, but my first thought is—could you create a segment that includes those URLs only?

text: there is not a great way to do this besides filtering out all the other pages

elements.text: there is not a great way to do this besides filtering out all the other pages

text: I've had something similar happen with a client....in my case they used dates in the URLs of the blogs so I was able to set up a filter based on that. Is there anything specifically identifiable that you can use as a filter?

text:
:wave:  Hey everyone! Question on spam bots - one of my clients' websites has been getting spammed by live traffic bots this week and it's really skewing our GA data.  They're a little tight on engineering resources and so far it just seems like janky data is the issue.

I'm kind of out of my element and googling to figure it out. Is it just a matter of filtering our GA data and the spam bots will move on? Does this need to be escalated to engineering (I read somewhere that this could be a DDOS attack)? Any insight / advice / resources would be really appreciated!

:point_right:  *Update:* Looks like it's just a benign annoyance that's tough to control/will stop eventually. Just means we'll have to be extra careful with filtering our traffic data until the spam stops. Sharing in case peeps come across this issue  :slightly_smiling_face:

elements.text:
Hey everyone! Question on spam bots - one of my clients' websites has been getting spammed by live traffic bots this week and it's really skewing our GA data.  They're a little tight on engineering resources and so far it just seems like janky data is the issue.

I'm kind of out of my element and googling to figure it out. Is it just a matter of filtering our GA data and the spam bots will move on? Does this need to be escalated to engineering (I read somewhere that this could be a DDOS attack)? Any insight / advice / resources would be really appreciated!
Update:

Looks like it's just a benign annoyance that's tough to control/will stop eventually. Just means we'll have to be extra careful with filtering our traffic data until the spam stops. Sharing in case peeps come across this issue

text:
I’m currently testing this on a site that also got a bunch of bot traffic over the weekend 

Use a test view for this, but, create a filter, custom, include Host Name, then put your website in there. Google filter by host name articles and you’ll see how to do it :+1:

text:
Ugh lol. That’s rough but I get why they did it. 

I would not use a filter, I would use content grouping. It’s non-destructive. Yes, it will be a pain to set up, you’ll need to continually update, also it’s not retroactive. But the pros outweighs the cons to me.

If you want it retroactive, I think you can use google data studio

If you want it retroactive, I think you can use google data studio

text: Those bot services sometimes do it (if it's around 1-2k pageviews) for the GA owner to follow up their source, go to their website and buy their product. Call it their own twisted way to do ads. :/ filtering with GA should do it, as it won't stop the visits, but you won't see the skewed data either, years before there was no such filter, and we had to write it ourselves / regex. Don't visit their websites though, that's how they win :grinning:
